Award.AwardTitle: CRII: NeTS OP: A Software Defined Approach to Laser-based Free Space Optical Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Free space optical (FSO) communications uses highly directional laser beams instead of radio frequencies to communicate data. FSO communication, especially for wireless networks, can be very low cost in nature for the bandwidth delivered. However, in spite of such obvious advantages, FSO links are rarely used in mobile wireless networks. This award seeks to investigate the leading cause of this phenomenon, namely the high beam alignment delay which poses a major roadblock to the deployment of FSO in mobile networks. Several innovative solutions will be explored in this project: the use of state of the art programmable optical elements that can split the beam into arbitrary patterns and help align the beams quicker, networking protocols that leverage this new capability in order to send data faster, and a novel low cost hardware platform that implements these techniques. Results from this work can improve the performance of the wireless backhaul solutions which is expected to be the basis of emerging access network architectures. As part of the proposed research, participation of underrepresented minorities will be encouraged by involving them in this project. The research outcomes from this project will be rolled back into curricula through the development of a special topics course for graduate students on free space optical communication.

In this project, programmable and tunable diffractive optical elements are leveraged to reduce the alignment delay and increase throughput, while new algorithms reconcile the literature on pointing, acquisition & tracking techniques with multi-hop RF-domain neighbor discovery algorithms. A novel FSO frontend for software defined radios, capable of coherent optical communication, will be developed to take advantage of the above enhancements. A simulator model will be extracted from the lessons learned during the hardware design phase, and fed back into the research community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Free space optical (FSO) communications use highly directional laser beams instead of radio frequencies to communicate data. FSO communication, especially for wireless networks, can be very low cost in nature for the bandwidth delivered. In spite of these advantages, FSO links are rarely used in mobile wireless networks. The high beam alignment delay, which is the leading cause of this phenomenon, poses a major roadblock to the deployment of FSO in mobile networks. In this project, the use of state of the art programmable micro electro-mechanical systems (MEMS)-based mirror arrays is investigated to reduce the beam alignment delay. The results from this project can improve the performance of wireless backhaul solutions which is expected to be the basis of emerging access network architectures such as 6G and 7G cellular networks.

In the first key result of this project, we have developed algorithms to reduce the time taken to find an incident laser beam on these MEMS arrays. We have shown that the link discovery latency can be reduced by 87-99% compared to state of art techniques, pushing the link acquisition time into milli- and micro-seconds instead of seconds and minutes. We were able to achieve this speedup through the use of information theory-based group testing algorithms, as opposed to raster scan or a Lissajous pattern scan. In addition, we have shown that making assumptions about the shape of the beam can further reduce this latency. Our technique is still amenable to implementation on a MEMS controller, just like the state of art techniques. These results have been published at peer reviewed international publication venues.

For the second key result, we have investigated how the transmitter in such networks can be made more efficient for certain traffic patterns. Compared to omni-directional wireless networks, broadcast and multicast traffic can impose an undue performance penalty on FSO networks. However, with a programmable (controllable) beam width, there are several improvements one can instrument in order to improve performance in such networks. We have shown that performance metrics can be improved by 5-10% in both static and mobile networks. The main intuition is that receivers can be grouped optimally into several sets, and multicast can be performed one set at a time. In the static scenario, such as one formed among 5G small cells, the optimal multicast problem can be cast as an NP-hard minimum weighted set cover problem. In the mobile scenario, such as one among small aerial vehicles, the problem is equivalent to the time-dependent prize collecting traveling salesman problem. We have developed a novel prize assignment strategy that is practical, as well as a medium access control algorithm.  

The project has resulted in a number of broader impacts. The lead graduate research assistant (Ph.D. student) who pioneered the proposed techniques under the PI's supervision is an Under-Represented Minority (URM) in Computer Science. This work constitutes the bulk of his Ph.D. dissertation. He is the lead author (first author) on five peer reviewed publications, with one other publication pending submission at the time of writing this report. Through the NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program, this project supported the involvement of two undergraduates in computer science research - one of whom is a URM in Computer Science.

    Atakora, Michael and Chenji, Harsha. (2020). Fast Neighbor Discovery in MEMS FSO Networks.  2020 International Conference on Computing, Networking and Communications (ICNC)

    Atakora, Michael and Chenji, Harsha. (2016). Optimal Multicasting in Hybrid RF/FSO DTNs.  Global Communications Conference (GLOBECOM), 2016 IEEE
